legal expenses of taxpayer's directors and agents in defending criminal charges
relation between charges and taxpayer's business activities
payment of expenses by taxpayer
whether capital or private expenditure

income tax assessment act 1936 (cth), s. 51(1). various criminal proceedings were brought against three of the taxpayer's directors, four of its agents, one of its associate companies and, for a time, the taxpayer itself. the charges related to the payment of secret commissions in the course of the taxpayer's business. the taxpayer expended some $280,000 in defending all the defendants, some of whom (not including the taxpayer) were convicted. the taxpayer sought a deduction for this amount under s. 51(1) of the income tax assessment act 1936 . there was evidence that the principal motive or purpose for the expenditure was to defend the three directors. the commissioner disallowed the taxpayer's claim, the taxpayer appealed to the supreme court of new south wales, and sheppard j. disallowed its appeal. the taxpayer appealed.
